Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Center: I/UCRC in Center for Energy-Smart Electronic Systems (ES2)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Full Proposal for an I/UCRC for Energy Efficient Electronic Systems

1134867 SUNY at Binghamton; Baghat Sammakia
1134810 Villanova University; Alfonso Ortega
1134821 University of Texas-Arlington; Dereje Agonafer

The Center for Energy Efficient Electronic Systems will focus on optimizing energy utilization in electronic systems. SUNY at Binghamton, Villanova University and the University of Texas at Arlington are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with SUNY at Binghamton as the lead institution

The proposed center will focus on the development of systematic methodologies for operating electronic systems, including data centers, as dynamic self sensing and regulating systems that are predictive and verified in real time. Algorithms will be developed to control cooling resources and to assist expert system schedulers to schedule and/or migrate workload to achieve optimal energy consumption. Thermal management resources will also be allocated dynamically in response to system needs. Problem-oriented research related to Thermal Management Protocols, Software Systems, Control Systems, and Implementation and Assessment, will be addressed during the Center's first five year program.

The proposed center will enable a significant reduction in energy consumption in electronic systems, including data centers, thereby potentially reducing electrical power consumption across the nation. This will, in turn, reduce the nations consumption of carbon-based fuels and related emissions. The center will attract a diverse group of students at the undergraduate and graduate levels, by providing industrially-relevant training required by graduates entering the workforce. The proposed center is committed to attracting talented and motivated students from all groups, and will integrate a variety of mechanisms across the partners, including enhancement of existing minority pipeline programs to exceed participation by women and under-represented students. The center also intends to leverage existing programming on its campuses to engage K-12 students in conversation on energy conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the proliferation of automation and electronic devices throughout most major industries, the amount of data being produced and the need to manage that data continues to grow. The power trend for electronic systems in general and server systems in particular also continues to grow at a significant rate, making energy optimization and thermal management a challenging task. The NSF I/UCRC for Energy-Smart Electronic systems was established in 2011 to address this challenge. The Center?s Vision is the creation and operation of energy-optimized data centers and electronic systems at any specified performance level by smart allocation and distribution of IT workload, smart integration of controlled on-demand cooling and smart elimination of energy waste and inefficiencies.  Binghamton University was the lead site during Phase I of ES2 research.

 

Intellectual Merit: ES2 focuses on the development of systematic methodologies for operating electronic systems, including data centers, as dynamic self-sensing and regulating cognitive systems that are predictive and verified in real time. The focus in Phase I was to develop new energy-optimization and thermal management models and designs, as well as tools and algorithms enabling electronic data systems to operate more efficiently and securely. This required a multi-disciplinary approach integrating software algorithms, control systems, thermal management and hardware. New models being developed have direct application to a variety of electronic/computing systems ranging all the way from the chip or device level to the system or data center level. They have informed product development and enhancement for ES2 member companies making their products more comprehensive and robust. Problem-oriented research related to software systems, control systems, thermal management, and implementation and experimental assessment have been addressed during the Center?s first five year program and will continue to be developed in Phase II in close collaboration with industry. A cluster award enabled evaluation of the energy efficiency and reliability improvements brought about by using hybrid AC/DC power instead of pure AC power in data centers. Each of hese technologies can be deployed in existing and new data centers to help them become more energy-efficient.

 

Broader Impacts: ES2, in promoting significant reductions in energy consumption in electronic systems, is contributing to the national agenda of pursing transformative technology breakthroughs that will help us meet our energy and environmental challenges. The continuing development of experimental and testing infrastructure at each of the ES2 partner universities has continued to accelerate the impact on the national and global data center community.  One of the emerging strengths of the ES2 Center developed during Phase I is that its participating universities have developed some of the most outstanding research quality facilities for data center related research in the world. A one-of-a-kind data center laboratory was constructed at Binghamton University which replicates a small to mid-sized industrial data center. Several industry members have made use of this data center lab by working closely with ES2 students and faculty to evaluate new products and technologies. Models and methodologies created by ES2 students and faculty have been used by industry in product development and product enhancement. The hybrid AC/DC power study demonstrated decisively the advantages of using DC power in data centers and the infrastructures needed to support DC power. It also demonstrated many of the inefficiencies in AC power delivery systems including conversion losses and the inevitable power phase imbalances that are rooted in workload variation and virtual machine management. During Phase I, ES2 researchers at Binghamton University have published over 70 papers in peer-reviewed journals and at technical conferences, yielding over 620 citations. ES2 researchers at Binghamton University have filed 10 patent applications or technical disclosures and 4 patents have been awarded as a result of ES2 research.

 

ES2 attracts a diverse group of students at the undergraduate and graduate levels, by providing industrially-relevant training required by graduates entering the workforce. ES2 has attracted talented and motivated students from all groups, including women and other underrepresented students, to advanced degrees in engineering. ES2 is educating broad-based scientists and engineers to create new innovations in energy efficient systems to be transferred to industry. ES2 engages industrial partners as center members on its Industrial Advisory Board where their input directly informs the center?s research. ES2 IAB members host Binghamton graduate students as interns, giving them much-needed experience solving real-world problems, and giving member companies the opportunity to gain experience with a potential new hire. In Phase I, ES2 at Binghamton University has graduated 7 doctoral and 2 master?s students, all of whom have gone on to be hired by industry members and non-members alike.  ES2 also provides partners with a technology transfer mechanism for new ES2 technologies.
